body.head: PCT 09 - Sweet-Grass Defeats the Blackfoot and Sarsi

p.seg: kîtahtawê êh-ayâcik wîkiwâhk , wawêyiwak , êh-sipwêhtêcik , ayahciyiniwah êh-ntonawâcik , ê-wîh-kakwêh-kimotamawâcik otêmiyiwah , ahpôh pêyakoyicih ê-wîh-nipahâcik ayahciyiniwah . Once upon a time some people got ready and went forth to look for Blackfoot, to try to steal their horses from them, or, if one was alone, to kill the Blackfoot.
êkosi itêyihtamwak . That was their purpose.
sipwêhtêwak ; mitâtaht ayênâniwosâp ihtasiwak nêhiyawak ôkih , oskinîkiwak . They set out; eighteen was the number of these Cree, young men.
kîtahtawê sîpiy êh-otihtahkik , êkotah êh-kapêsicik , ê-wîh-nipâcik tipiskâkih , In time, when they came to a stream, they made camp there, to sleep that night.
êh-tipiskâyik kisinâyiw , êh-misponiyik . When night came, there was frost, and snow fell.
piyisk wâpan ; misponiyiw . Dawn came; it snowed.
hâw , mâcîk , itêwak oskinîkiwah ; “Now go hunt,” they said to the young men;

seg.gloss: “When the storm ceases we shall go on.
If you kill a buffalo, we shall not go hungry.”

p.seg: tâpwêh pêyak oskinîkiw pasikôw , êh-sipwêhtêt , ê-wîh-kakwêh-wâpamât mostoswah , êh-mâcît . So a youth arose and set out to look for buffalos, to hunt.
pôtih êh-pimohtêt , kâ-wâpamât iyahciyiniwah êh-pêyakoyit . There as he walked along, he caught sight of a lone Blackfoot.
pê-kîwêw onwîcêwâkanah itah k-âyâyit . He came back to his companions.

êh-takohtêt ômisi itêw :
niwâpamâw ayahciyiniw êh-pêyakot , itêw . When he got there he said, “I saw a lone Blackfoot,” he told them.
at-sipwêhtêwak , êh-itohtêcik itah ka-wâpamimiht . they set out one after the other and went to the place where the Blackfoot had been seen.
cîkih êy-ihtâcik , wâpamêwak misatimwah êh-kîwêtisahwâyit . When they were close by, they saw him driving home horses.
môskîstawêwak , ê-wîh-kakwêh-maskamâcik ôhih misatimwah . They attacked him, to rob him of his horses.
awah ê-wâpamât nêhiyawah ayahciyiniw , tapasîw , êh-sipwêtisahwât misatimwah . When the Blackfoot saw the Cree, he fled, driving on the horses.
êh-pimipahtât , kisiwâk sîpiy ayâyiw , êkotah ê-pinasiwêtisahwât ôhi misatimwah . As he ran along, a river was near there; down to it he drove the horses.
êkotah êh-wîkicik okih ayahciyiniwak . That was the camping-place of those Blackfoot.
êkotah ê-sâkêwêcik tah sîpiyihk nêhiyawak , kâ-wâpahtahkik mîkiwâhpah . When the Cree came out upon the river, there they saw the tents.
tapasîwak ôki nêhiyawak . The Cree fled.
wawêyiwak iyahciyiniwak , êh-têhtapicik otêmiwâwa , êh-nawaswâtâcik ôhih nêhiyawah . The Blackfoot got ready and mounted their horses, and pursued the Cree.

ê-pmpahtâcik nêhiyawak , kotak êh-pasahcâyik ê-sakâyik êkotah êh-itohtêcik , kâ-wâpahtahkik kotakah mîkiwâhpah . As the Cree, in their flight, came to another wooded gully, there they saw some other tents.
mîn êwakonih iyahciyiniwah . These people too were Blackfoot.
êkotah ohcih tapasîwak . From here again they fled.
min êwakonih môskîstâkwak . These people, too, attacked them.
êkwah mihcêtiyiwah , wiyawâw ayênâniwosâp êy-ihtasicik . By this time the others were many, and of them therefore only eighteen.
wâpahtamwak êh-minahikoskâyik ; êkotah sêskisiwak . They saw a spruce-grove; they fled into it.
hâw , oskinîkîtik , wâtihkêk , itwêwak okih nêhiyawak . “Come, young men, dig a trench,” said the Cree.
âsay wâsakâm ayâyiwah ayahciyiniwah . By this time the Blackfoot were all around.
âsay mâcih-pâskiswâwak ; wiyawâw mînah pâskiswêwak . Now they began to be shot at; and they, too, shot at the others.
êkwah nôtinitôwak . So they fought each other.
wâtihkêwak mistah ôkô ôskinîkiwak , êkotah êh-apicik wâtihk . Those young men dug a large trench, and they stayed in the trench.

ômisi isiyîhkâtêw omah wâtihkân :
mênisk
isiyîhkâtêw . Such a trench is called “earthwork.”

ôkih k-âyimisicik êyôkonik ômis îsiyîhkâsôwak :
êh-nâpêhkâsocik
isiyihkâsôwak , namoya êh-pîhtokêcik wâtihkânihk , êyôkonik êh-âhkamêyimocik êh-nôtinikêcik . The men who fight so as to be feared are called “braves,” those who do not go into the pit but courageously fight.
piyisk kinwêsk nôtinikêwak . They fought for a long time.
piyisk tipiskâw . At last night came.
êh-tipiskâyik , kotakah mînah takosiniyiwah ayahciyiniwah , êkonih mînah êh-nôtinikocik . At nightfall some more Blackfoot arrived, and these too joined in the fight against the Cree.

piyis wâsakâm êkotah kotawêyiwah ,
êkâh ta-sipwêhtêcik , êh-itêyimikocik . Finally they built fires all around, intending to bring it about that the Cree should not leave that place.
piyis wâpaniyiw . At last day dawned.
namoya nipâwak , êh-nôtinikêcik . They did not sleep for fighting.
wiyawâw nama kêkway nipahikwak ôkih nêhiyawak . the latter had killed none of the Cree.

piyisk ê-sâkâstêyik , kotakah mînah takohtêyiwah êh-pêh-nâh-nâtamâtôyit , êh-pê-wîcihitoyit , ê-wîh-kakwêh-mêscihikocik . When daylight came, again some other Blackfoot arrived, to relieve the others, and help them try to massacre the Cree.
mâkah nama kêkway nipahikwak ; cêskwah wiyawâw mihcêt nipahêwak . But they killed none at all of the Cree, while the latter killed many of them.
êwakô kapê-kîsik nôtinitôwak , piyisk ê-wîh-tipiskâk , nistoh pikoh nôtinikêwak nêhiyawak . They fought all that day, until, toward nightfall, only three of the Cree were still fighting.
ômisi isiyîhkâsôw awa nêhiyaw k-âyimisit êh-nôtinikêt : wîhkasko-kisêyin isiyihkâsôw . This was the name of the Cree who fought most redoubtably: Sweet-Grass was his name.
êkwah kotak mistahi-maskwah isiyîhkâsôw . Another was called Big-Bear,
êkwah kotak napatê-kîsik isiyîhkâsôw ; êwakô nôhtâwiy . and the other was called Half-sky; he was my father.
êkwah êh-tipiskâyik , âsay mînah kotakah takohtêyiwah iyahciyiniwah . Then, at night, still more Blackfoot arrived.
âsay mâka mihcêt nipahêwak iyahciyiniwah . But by this time they had slain many Blackfoot.
êkwah mistahi êh-tipiskâk , nêstosiw mistahi-maskwah ; Then, late in the night, Big-Bear got tired;
pîhtokêw wâtihkânihk , nîso-kîsikâw , kêkâc nîso-tipiskâw êh-nôtinikêt , kâ-nêstosit . he went into the pit, wearied from having fought two days and almost two nights.
nîso piko êkwah nôtinikêwak nêhiyawak . Then only two Cree were fighting.

wâsakâm kisiwâk êh-pêy-itohtêyit iyahciyiniwah , iskotêw êh-tahkonamiyit , êyak ôhci êh-pakamahokocik ,
kah-kakwêh-kîsisôwak , êh-itêyimikocik , As the Blackfoot came close from all sides, bearing fire, with which they struck at the Cree, meaning to burn them,
piyisk , mistikwah wâsakâm ê-kîh-astâcik omêniskiwâhk , piyisk êwakonih saskitêyiwah ; at last the sticks which they had placed round their earthwork caught fire,
mâka namoya kîsisôwak . but the Cree were not burned.

kîtahtawê awah napatê-kîsik k-êsiyîhkâsot êwakô ospiskwanihk , ôhi otîhiyah êkotah , pahkihtiniyiw môsosiniy , ayahciyiniwah êh-pâskisokot ; Then at one time he whose name was Half-sky, a bullet hit him in the back, here at his shoulder-blade, as the Blackfoot shot at him,
mâka namoya pîkopayiyiwah wasakayah , namoya ê-kîh-pikwahokot ; but his skin was not broken, he was not pierced by the bullet;
mâkah oskan pîkopayiw . but the bone was broken.
êkosi êkwah namoya kîh-miciminam pâskisikan . So now he was not able to hold a gun.
ospiton napatê namoya âpacihtâw . He was not able to use his arm on that side.
êkwah pêyakôw wîhkasko-kisêyin êh-nôtinikêt . now Sweet-Grass was alone in the fight.
piyisk kisiwâk êkwah ayâyiwah iyahciyiniwah . At last the Blackfoot were quite near.

kîtahtawê wîhkaskô-kisêyin kâ-wâpamât kisiwâk mistikwah êh-cimasôyit , êkotah êh-pê-nahapiyit , êh-âkôsimoyit , ê-misikitiyit mistikwah . Then, at one time, Sweet-Grass saw, where a tree stood close by, that a Blackfoot came and crouched near it, shielding himself behind it, behind the big tree.

êkotah ohci wâpamêw êh-pê-mihcêtiyit ôh îyahciyiniwah , êkwah ê-wîh-kakwêh-otihtinikocik owâtihkâniwâhk . On that side he saw the Blackfoot coming in numbers and making ready to storm them in their trench.
pôtih aw âyahciyiniw kâ-nîkânohtêt mistikohk k-âpit . There, by the tree, sat the Blackfoot who marched in the lead.

awah nêhiyaw itêh k-ôh-ayât êkotêh ohcih , awa mistik kayâs ês ê-kîh-kîsisot , wâpamêw ôhi mistikwah , êh-kîh-wâsahîhkasôyit . From where he was, that Cree saw that tree, and saw that it had of old been burned, struck by lightning.
êkosi êkwah ôtah pâskiswêw mistikwah awa nêhiyaw . So the Cree shot at the tree itself.
nipahâw . he was killed.
êkosi ôhi otôskinîkîmah owîcêwâkanah kahkiyaw tapasiyiwah , êh-nipahiht êh-okimâwit aw âyahciyiniw . Then his followers and companions all fled, when the Blackfoot chief was slain.
êkosi êkwah pônih-tasinamwak ; pôni-nôtinitôwak . Thereupon they ceased firing; they ceased fighting.

kîtahtawê kâ-matwê-pîkiskwêt aw âyahciyiniw êh-nêhiyawêt ;
awêniki kiyawâw ? êkosîy itwêw . Then the Blackfoot called out, in Cree; “Who are you?” he asked.

êkosi ômisi itwêwak nêhiyawak :
nam âwiyak okimâw ôtah , itwêwak nêhiyawak . Then thus answered the Cree: “There are no chiefs here,” they said.
âtah nîso okimâwak nêhiyawak : To be sure, two of the Cree were chiefs.
wîhkaskô-kisêyin êyoko pêyak okimâw ; êkwah kotak mistahê-maskwah , êwako mînah okimâw ; Sweet-Grass was a chief, and Big-Bear also was a chief;
mâka namoya wîh-wîhtamawêwak . but they did not want to tell him this.

piyisk aw îyahciyiniw matwê-pikiskwêw ,
tân-tahtoh kinipahikawinâwâw , nêhiyâtik ? êkosi itwêw . Later the Blackfoot called; “How many of you have been slain, O Cree?” he asked.
nama kêkway , itwêwak nêhiyawak . “None at all,” answered the Cree. KR: Book has the three sentences of this paragraph on separate lines and indented as paragraphs, but with no paragraph number.
cikêmâ nama kêkway nipahâwak nêhiyawak . And in fact, none of the Cree had been killed.
kiyawâw mâka ? itêwak nêhiyawak . “And you?” the Cree asked them.

ômisîy itwêw ayahciyiniw :
têpakôhp mistahi êh-okimâwicik kaskitêwayastak kâ-nipahâyêkok ; Thus spoke the Blackfoot: “Seven great chiefs of the Blackfoot you have slain;

seg.gloss: and six Blood chiefs you have slain;

seg.q: êkwah sasîwak nêwo okimâwak kinipahâwâwak ; êkwah pîkanôwîniwak nîso okimâwak .
seg.gloss: and four Sarsi chiefs you have slain, and two Piegan chiefs.

seg.q: namoya mihcêt ôtah ayâwak pîkanôwîniwak ; mâkah ôki kotakak kâ-wâh-wîhakik , itôwahk mihcêt okimâwak kinipahâwâwak .
seg.gloss: There are not many Piegans here, but of those whom I have named, of them you have killed many chieftains.

p.seg: êkosi itwêw aw âyahciyiniw . Thus spoke that Blackfoot.
êkosi tâpwê pôni-pâskisotôwak . Then really they did cease shooting at each other.

êkwah ôki nêhiyawak pêyak nâpêsis êkotah êh-wîcêwât , wâtihkânihk ê-kîh-apit awa nâpêsis ,
mahtih nika-wâpamâwak iyahciyiniwak , itwêw awa nâpêsis . And among those Cree a young lad who was with them and had stayed in the trench, “Let me go look at the Blackfoot,” said this boy.
êkâ wiyah ! itik owîcêwâkanah . “Do not!” his comrades said to him.
âhci pikoh wayawîw wâtihkânihk ohcih . Nevertheless he went out of the trench.
kîpiwêpahwâw , wawikanihk êh-tawahoht , êh-kaskâwikanêhoht . he reeled over, struck in the spine, the bone shattered.
êkosi otinêwak , êh-ahâcik wâtihkânihk . They got him and laid him in the trench.
êkosi kâ-kîh-ititân ; osâm namoya kipa-pêhtên , êh-itâcik ôhi nâpêsisah ; “This is what I told you; but you did not listen,” they told him;
kîh-tâpwêhtaman , namoya kâ-kîh-tawahokohtayak , itêwak . “If you had obeyed, you would not have been wounded,” they said to him.
êkosi êkwah pôyôwak . Then they stopped.
êkwah kîwêwak ôk âyahciyiniwak . The Blackfoot went home.

êkwah nêhiyawak ay-apiwak êkotah ,
mâskôc tâpwêh kipônihikonawak , êh-itwêcik . The Cree stayed there, saying, “Perhaps they really have given us up.”

kîtahtawê pêyak awa nâpêw ,
mahtih nka-wâpamâwak ; mahti tâpwê kê-kîwêcik , êh-itwêt , ê-sipwêhtêt . Presently one man said, “Let me go look at them; suppose they really will turn out to have gone home,” said he and departed.
pôtih namoya wâpamêw , êh-kîwêt . He did not see them; he came back.

nôhtêyâpâkwêwak , nîso-kîsikâw nîso-tipiskâw êkâh êh-minihkwêcik , êkâh êh-mîcisocik , namoya êh-nipâcik . They were thirsty, not having drunk for two days and nights, and having neither eaten nor slept.
êkosi pasikôwak ê-wîh-sipwêhtêcik . So they got up to go away.
ê-wîh-nakasiyêk cî ? êkos îtwêw awa nâpêsis . “And are you going to leave me?” asked that boy.
âyisk namoya kîh-pimohtêw awa nâpêsis . For he was not able to walk.

seg.gloss: It is only that we are thirsty.

p.seg: miskamâhkô nipiy ka-pê-nâtikawin , êh-itâcik ôhi nâpêsisah , êh-wayêsimâcik , êh-pê-kîwêcik , êh-pê-tapasîcik . When we have found water, you will be fetched,” they told him, deceiving him, for they were going to flee for home.
êkosi kahkiyaw pimâtisiwak , wîkiwâhk ê-takohtêcik . So they all stayed alive and reached their village.

awa wîhkasko-kisêyin oskotâkay wâpôwayân nistomitanaw nîsohayiwâk tahtwayak , êkosi nama nânitaw mâ-misiwêw êh-pikwâhoht . Sweet-Grass' coat and blanket had thirty-two bullet-holes, but in no spot was he wounded. LB on {tahtwayak}: The word “it was pierced” was not spoken, but supplied by gesture.
êkosi êôkôw âcimowin . So goes this story.
namoya kayâs . It is not old
mâskôc mitâtahtomitanaw askiy . Perhaps a hundred years.
